title: Case exchange
content:
You can integrate two OpenText Service Management systems for case exchange. The two systems can belong to the same suite instance or two different instances.

 

Any mention of SMAX in this document refers to OpenText Service Management, which was formerly known as SMAX.

    Change log

    The following table outlines the revision history of the templates used for case exchange between two Service Management systems.

    VersionChange description
    2021.11Initial release
    2022.05Added attachment support for case creation
    24.4

    Added the following enhancements:

    • Attachment support for comments
    • Keep formatting of comments 

    Use cases

    The following are out-of-the-box use cases of case exchange between two Service Management systems.

    Incident exchange

    The following diagram depicts this use case.

      Request exchange

      The following diagram depicts this use case. 

      How it works

      All the mentioned use cases are based on the Integration Studio. When creating an integration with another Service Management system, you need to define one or more scenarios for the integration and create appropriate business rules for each scenario so that the system calls the Integration Studio to run this scenario under a specified condition.

      Each scenario defines actions against the source and target systems. For a list of supported actions, see Integration Studio connectors.

      The integration use cases described in this document serve as examples to inspire and guide your integration efforts. However, they should not be considered as prescriptive or guaranteed solutions for your particular scenario. The examples may or may not be applicable for your license edition.

      Set up the integration

      As an example, the procedure below will set up the integration to implement the Incident Exchange use case. This procedure consists of steps that you must perform on the source tenant and target tenant. In this example, the source tenant is an IT tenant, and the target tenant is a Service Provider tenant.

      Prepare two integration users 

      We recommend creating a dedicated integration user for each system.

      To prepare an integration user for the IT tenant: 

      1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user. For example, use it_integration as the user name. 
      2. Log in to the agent interface of the IT tenant as the tenant admin, and do the following:
        1. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the it_integration user, and assign these roles to the user: Incident Analyst, Incident Coordinator, Incident Manager, and Incident Process Owner.
        2. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People > Roles, and create a new role with Create, View, and Update permissions for the External reference and External system record types.
        3. Assign the new role to the it_integration user.

      Similarly, create an integration user service_integration for the Service Provider tenant, and assign the required roles to this user. 

      Prepare groups used for case exchange with the remote system

      To prepare groups for case exchange, follow these steps in both the IT tenant and the Service Provider tenant:

      1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
      2. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People > Groups.
      3. Create a new group for the tenant. 
        In this example, create a group Service Providerfor the IT tenant, and a group IT System for the Service Provider tenant.

      If your records for case exchange must be assigned to more than one assignment group, perform the steps for each group.

      Export certificates

      For the two tenants to connect with each other, you will need to do either of the following later:

      • If not using the OPB Agent, upload both root CA certificates to the other side
      • If using the OPB Agent, upload both certificates to the OPB agent

      In this step, you need to export both certificates in PEM format. 

      To export the certificates, do the following for each tenant:

      1. Open the tenant URL in a web browser.
      2. Export the root CA certificate to a file in base-64 encoded X.509 format. 

      Now you should have two certificate files. For example, it_CA.cer for the IT tenant and provider_CA.cer for the Service Provider tenant.

      Download and install the OPB Agent if needed

      If the source system can directly connect to the target (endpoint) system, there's no need to use the On-Premises Bridge (OPB) agent. If there's a web application firewall deployed in front of the target system, the source system needs to use the OPB agent to connect to the target system. For instance, the source tenant system is running on a public cloud and the target tenant system is running in a firewalled on-premises environment. 

      To use the OPB Agent for the integration, perform the following steps.

      If the OPB Agent is already installed and connected to your source tenant system, skip steps 1 and 2 below. 
      1. In the source tenant system, download and install the OPB agent. Use the integration user (it_integration) to install the OPB Agent, and you need to assign the integration user the OPB Remote Agent role. 
      2. Import the CA certificates of the source tenant system into the OPB agent's trusted keystore.
      3. Import the CA certificates of the target tenant system into the OPB agent's trusted keystore.
      4. In the source tenant system, add an agent. You will need to specify this agent when creating an endpoint for the target system. 
      5. Launch the Endpoint Credentials Manager, and create a credentials record for the endpoint with the Rest Executor Domain 2.0 endpoint type. The credentials record can use the integration user (service_integration) created for the target system. 

      For details, see How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Windows or How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Linux. 

      Configure the IT tenant

      Perform the following steps in the IT tenant as the tenant admin. 

      Create an endpoint

      Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

      1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
      2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints. 
      3. Click Add.
      4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint, and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint. 
      5. Click Configure, and then complete the fields depending on whether you're using the OPB agent for the integration.  
        If you're not using the OPB agent, complete these fields.
        FieldValue
        Agent

        Select Agentless.

        Authentication typeSelect SMAX.
        ProtocolSelect https.
        Base URLEnter the base URL of the Service Provider tenant: https://<FQDN>
        Tenant IDEnter the tenant ID of the Service Provider tenant.
        UsernameEnter the username of the integration user for connecting to the Service Provider tenant. In this example, enter service_integration.
        PasswordEnter the password of the integration user for connecting to the Service Provider tenant. In this example, enter the password of service_integration.
        Confirm passwordRe-enter the password.
        Certificate typeSelect X.509.
        Certificate formatSelect PEM.
        Server certificate

        Open the root CA certificate file of the Service Provider tenant (in this example, provider_CA.cer) in a text editor, and then copy and paste the content to this field. If the content is invalid, an error occurs when you click Save in the next step. 

        The certificate content must resemble the following.

        -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
        MIIF2TCCBMGgAwIBAgIQBMF1U8hY8bivE0+JHx922jANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQsFADBG
        MQswCQYDVQQGEwJVUzEPMA0GA1UEChMGQW1hem9uMRUwEwYDVQQLEwxTZXJ2ZXIg
        Q0EgMUIxDzANBgNVBAMTBkFtYXpvbjAeFw0yMTEwMTEwMDAwMDBaFw0yMjExMDky
        MzU5NTlaMBsxGTAXBgNVBAMTEHhpZS5pdHNtYS1uZy5vcmcwggEiMA0GCSqGSIb3
        1oIvQfpl2gj0S6JSJAYjJnY7HKCa7mkzBMiiXWI5aHMZfl1FsaNARM10LUpto61f
        Ivk/SDNlOqVXuzGMTZkJBVZVmK5lNLvBB1Gk9+QlJ+SuUOW7FW2K5U+oQKWsHtvH
        C/DHn6yyhvqWes9q6A==
        -----END CERTIFICATE-----

        If you're using the OPB agent, complete these fields.
        FieldValue
        Agent

        Select the agent that you created for the integration. 

        Authentication typeSelect SMAX.
        ProtocolSelect https.
        Base URLEnter the base URL of the Service Provider tenant: https://<FQDN>
        Tenant IDEnter the tenant ID of the Service Provider tenant.
        CredentialsSelect the credentials record that you've created for the endpoint in the Endpoint Credential Manager. 
      6. Click Save. The system displays a message indicating the endpoint configuration has been successfully saved. 

      Create an integration

      Create an integration and configure one or more scenarios to define the business logic for forwarding tickets and synchronizing ticket updates to the Service Provider tenant.

      To create an integration:

      1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio. 
      2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
      3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the IT tenant and activate the integration.
      4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.
      5. Select SMAX (under OpenText) as the connector, select the SMAX endpoint that you created earlier, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
      6. Click Save.

      Configure a scenario

      Two out-of-the-box templates are available for case exchange between two Service Management systems: Request to Request, and Incident to Incident. The following describes how to configure a scenario based on the Incident to Incident template. This template provides predefined actions that allow the system to trigger different actions against the IT and Service Provider systems.

      For more detailed instructions on configuring a scenario, see the How do I...? topic.
      If you want to delete an existing scenario, select the scenario from the left navigation pane and then click Delete scenario. 

      To configure a scenario:

      1. Click Add scenario.
      2. Enter a name for the scenario, for example, Incident to Incident. 
      3. In the Template field, select Incident to Incident (under OpenText SMAX) from the list. 
      4. Click Save to add the scenario.
      5. (Optional) Repeat the steps above to add the other scenarios to your integration.
       Using templates will make the integration configuration easier than starting from scratch. If you don't select this option, you'll have to manually add your own logic, starting from a blank page.


      Actions required before using the Incident to Incident scenario

      In the Default parameters rule at the start of the process logic, enter the following details.

      ParameterDescription
      TargetSystemNameOptional.
      Enter a display name for the target tenant. For example: 'Service Provider system'.
      TargetSystemUserNameOptional.
      Enter a display name for the user that will appear in the discussions area of the exchanged data.
      SourceSystemNameOptional.
      Enter a display name for the source tenant. For example: 'IT system'.
      SourceSystemUserNameOptional.
      Enter a display name for the username that will appear in the discussions area of the exchanged data.
      RequestedByEnter the UPN of a person that exists in the target tenant. This user will be the "Reported by" person of each incident forwarded to the target tenant.
      For example, you can enter the UPN of the integration user created for the target tenant. In this example, enter service_integration.
      AssignmentGroupEnter the UPN of an assignment group that exists in the target tenant. This value will be displayed in the "Service desk group" field. Here, we enter the UPN of the IT System created above.
      CategorySpecify the Display Label of a category that exists in the target tenant. This value will be used as the default category for records forwarded to the target tenant. For example: 'Cloud'.
      ServiceSpecify the Display Label of a service that exists in the target tenant. This value will be used as the default service for records forwarded to the target tenant. For example: 'Catalog'.
      TenantIDReplace the placeholder value for the first parameter of the get_endpoint_info function with the endpoint name for the integration. The following is an example value of the field after replacing the placeholder value: get_endpoint_info('Service Provider system', 'tenantId').
      SourceSystemBaseUrlKeep the default value.
      TargetSystemBaseUrlReplace the placeholder value for the first parameter of the get_endpoint_info function with the endpoint name for the integration. The following is an example value of the field after replacing the placeholder value: get_endpoint_info('Service Provider system', 'baseUrl').
      CommentFilter

      Optional.

      If required, change the filter expression to fetch the comments to exchange.

      Create business rules in the IT tenant

      In the IT tenant, create business rules for the Incident record type to trigger the forwarding of eligible incidents to the Service Provider tenant.

      1. Log in to the IT tenant as the tenant admin.
      2. Go to Administration > Configuration > Studio.
      3. Select the Incident record type from the drop-down list on the left corner, and then select the Processes and Rules tab.

      4. Select Normal > Resolution >Initial Support in the left pane, and then select the Rules tab in the right pane.

        Add the business rule at the appropriate level according to your business needs. Avoid adding the rule at the root level because this might cause the integration scenario to be triggered multiple times.
      5. Click Add next to After applying changes, and then select "If...Then" rule.
      6. Add and configure a rule based on the Call Integration Studio template:
        ParameterDescription
        ExpressionEnter a condition. To avoid a loop when the Integration Studio updates the record in the current system, ensure that the integration user is part of the condition. For example: ${current_user.Upn != 'it_integration'&& entity.ExpertGroup.Name=='Service Provider'}
        Integration TypeSelect the integration that you created for the source tenant.
        Scenario NameSelect the scenario you created for the integration. 
      7. Select Normal > Validation > Review from the left panel, and then select the Rules tab in the right pane.
      8. In the After applying changes section, click Add to add another complex rule by selecting the Call Integration Studio template:
        ParameterDescription
        ExpressionEnter a condition. To avoid a loop when the Integration Studio updates the record in the current system, ensure that the integration user is part of the condition. For example: ${current_user.Upn != 'it_integration'&&entity.ExpertGroup.Name=='Service Provider'}
        Integration TypeSelect the integration that you created for the source tenant.
        Scenario NameSelect the scenario you created for the integration.
      9. Click Save. 

      Configure the Service Provider tenant

      Perform similar steps in the target tenant:

      1. Log in to the Service Provider tenant as the tenant admin.
      2. Create an endpoint, an integration, and a scenario. For details, refer to the "Configure the IT tenant" section above.
      3. Create a business rule.

        Go to Administration > Configuration > Studio.

        Select the Incident record type from the drop-down list on the left corner, and then click Processes and Rules.

        Select Normal > Resolution >Initial Support from the left panel, and then select the Rules tab in the right pane.

        Click Add in the After applying changes section to add a complex rule by selecting the Call Integration Studio template:
         

        ParameterDescription
        ExpressionEnter a condition. To avoid a loop when the Integration Studio updates the record in the current system, ensure that the integration user is part of the condition. For example: ${current_user.Upn != 'service_integration'&&entity.ServiceDeskGroup.Upn=='ITSystem'}
        Integration TypeSelect the integration that you created for the target tenant.
        Scenario NameSelect the scenario you created for the integration.
      4. Click Save.

      Use the integration

      Perform the following steps to use the integration and verify the integration setup. 

      Create an incident in the IT tenant

      1. Log in to the agent interface of the IT tenant as a user with access to the Incident record type.
      2. Navigate to Run > Incident.
      3. Create a new incident and enter values in the required fields that can move the incident to the Initial Support phase.
      4. Open the incident and set the Expert group value to Service Provider.
      5. Click Save.

      6. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints, and open the endpoint record for the integration to view the status of each rule in the Incident to Incident scenario. Make sure all rules in the scenario have been executed and none of them have the Failed status. For more information, see Use the Integration Studio.

        Each time you complete a task that must trigger the scenario, you can perform this step to verify that the scenario rules have been successfully executed.
      7. Go back to the incident detail page and refresh the page. The system loads a new "External assignment" section, which displays the Remote id, Remote status, Remote system, and URL for the incident created in the target system.
      8. Click the URL in the External assignment section. This opens the target tenant. Log in to the tenant, and the system displays the incident created by the Incident to Incident scenario.

      Work on the incident in the Service Provider tenant

      When a user in the Service Provider tenant starts working on the incident, the user can perform the following steps to inform the user in the IT tenant:

      1. In the Service Provider tenant, open the incident created by the Incident to Incident scenario.

      2. Go to the Discussions tab and enter a comment.

      3. Select External service desk in the To field.

      4. Click Add & Save Record. The comment is added, and the system triggers a case exchange with the IT tenant.
      5. Log in to the IT tenant.

      6. Open the original incident. The system displays the comment in the Discussions tab of the incident record.

      Resolve the incident in the Service Provider tenant

      When the user in the Service Provider tenant finds the solution for the incident, the user can perform the following steps to resolve the incident:

      1. In the Service Provider tenant, open the incident created by the Incident to Incident scenario.

      2. Enter the solution and the completion code.

      3. Click Save. The system triggers a case exchange with the IT tenant.
      4. Log in to the IT tenant.

      5. Open the original incident. The system displays the incident resolution.

      Close the incident in both tenants

      As the last step, the user manually closes the incident in the IT tenant and the Service Provider tenant.
